issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
We have been finding that range ghosts appear in results from Hadoop via Pig.  This could also happen if rows don't have data for the slice predicate that is given.  This leads to having to do a painful amount of defensive checking on the Pig side, especially in the case of range ghosts.

We would like to add an option to skip rows that have no column values in it.  That functionality existed before in core Cassandra but was removed because of the performance penalty of that checking.  However with Hadoop support in the RecordReader, that is batch oriented anyway, so individual row reading performance isn't as much of an issue.  Also we would make it an optional config parameter for each job anyway, so people wouldn't have to incur that penalty if they are confident that there won't be those empty rows or they don't care.

It could be parameter cassandra.skip.empty.rows and be true/false.

fields.summary: Skip rows with empty columns when slicing entire row

creator.name: jeromatron
creator.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

reporter.name: jeromatron
reporter.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I don't like the idea of adding flags to change behavior.

What I think we *could* do is not bother including empty rows in the resultset, IF we are doing a slice query for the entire row.  (Since, as soon as the tombstones expire, they will be gone anyway.)

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: is it more expensive/complicated to do it for an empty slice or is that just orthogonal to this since that is handled in a different place?

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: sylvain points out that doing this at the Thrift layer would break the row count contract.  We could still do this at the CFRR level.

bq. is it more expensive/complicated to do it for an empty slice

empty result for entire row slice means it really will be gone when tombstone expires, so the two are semantically equivalent.  this is not the case for a smaller slice; an empty result for that could mean "there is data in the row, just not in the slice you requested."  so leaving that out would be an error.

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: Simple patch to skip results that have no values for the key.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: Brandon was saying that empty slice comment only referred to core Cassandra, so in the CFRR I just skipped any key didn't have values - hoping that isSetColumns handles all cases for that.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: v2 is tested to skip results with no columns and tombstones.  Also fixed where an exception would occur because lastRow looked at the altered set of rows.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: Added a configuration property cassandra.skip.empty.results which defaults to false.  We can't skip just complete empty rows because there is no way to tell if the complete row is empty based on a result from a slice predicate.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: skip.empty.results should probably be 'skip.empty.rows' or 'skip.tombstones' and there needs to be a check on the predicate to see if it covers the entire row, and if so suppress the tombstone, but if not return the empty slice.

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: v4 updates the config var to cassandra.skip.empty.rows and only does so if the slice predicate is empty.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: If we are only only skipping when it the predicate covers the entire row (which is the Right Thing imo), why do we need the configuration setting?  Can't we make it just always skip?  Look at it this way: you're giving the same result that the user would see anyway if he had a lower tombstone grace.

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: True - wouldn't matter.

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
updateAuthor.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

comments.body: v5 removes the skip.empty.rows option making this behavior always-on.

author.name: jeromatron
author.emailAddress: jeremy dot hanna1234 at gmail dot com

updateAuthor.name: jeromatron
